title: 108_s1531
content: The Act is titled the "Chief Justice John Marshall Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. The "Chief Justice John Marshall Commemorative Coin Act" acknowledges John Marshall's significant contributions to the United States, highlighting his role as Chief Justice and his service in various government positions. The Act also outlines the specifications for the commemorative coin. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 400,000 $1 coins in honor of Chief Justice John Marshall's 250th birth anniversary. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The coins minted under this Act in honor of Chief Justice John Marshall will have a design emblematic of his contributions to the United States. The design will include inscriptions of the coin's value, the year "2005", and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant organizations and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at one designated Mint facility starting January 1, 2005, with minting authority ending on December 31, 2005. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act include a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges received will be paid to the Supreme Court Historical Society for historical research, supporting programs at the Supreme Court, and collecting historical items. The Society will be audited as per the requirements of title 31, United States Code. The Society will be audited according to the requirements of title 31, United States Code, for the amounts received under subsection (b). SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the Government for minting coins and may only sell coins if full payment, security, or a guarantee of payment is received. Passed the Senate on November 21, 2003. Attest: EMILY J. REYNOLDS, Secretary.
